posts.post_content: I've faced this card many times in my friend's U/B mill deck. It's a decent card for dedicated mill decks, but it doesn't usually mill for all that much after the target has already been hit by [Hedron Crab](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Hedron Crab), [Tome Scour](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tome Scour)(s), [Glimpse the Unthinkable](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glimpse the Unthinkable)(s), [Mind Funeral](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind Funeral)(s), and/or [Archive Trap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Archive Trap)(s). It also has to compete with [Haunting Echoes](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Haunting Echoes), [Nemesis of Reason](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nemesis of Reason), and hardcast [Archive Trap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Archive Trap) for 5 mana drops. The best use I've ever seen for this card is using it on yourself in a graveyard based deck. However, there are easier ways to mill yourself, such as [Cephalid Illusionist](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Cephalid Illusionist) + [Nomads En-Kor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nomads En-Kor), which was common in legacy back in 2007.
posts.html:
I've faced this card many times in my friend's U/B mill deck. It's a decent card for dedicated mill decks, but it doesn't usually mill for all that much after the target has already been hit by Hedron Crab, Tome Scour(s), Glimpse the Unthinkable(s), Mind Funeral(s), and/or Archive Trap(s). It also has to compete with Haunting Echoes, Nemesis of Reason, and hardcast Archive Trap for 5 mana drops. The best use I've ever seen for this card is using it on yourself in a graveyard based deck. However, there are easier ways to mill yourself, such as Cephalid Illusionist + Nomads En-Kor, which was common in legacy back in 2007.

posts.post_content: Milling is fun, but some cards and combos make it too easy to mill -- [Traumatize](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Traumatize) isn't as bad as [Painter's Servant](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Painter's Servant) + [Grindstone](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Grindstone), but it will destroy your library no matter what size it is, and for that reason, it's a very silly card that shouldn't scale the way it does.
posts.html:
Milling is fun, but some cards and combos make it too easy to mill -- Traumatize isn't as bad as Painter's Servant + Grindstone, but it will destroy your library no matter what size it is, and for that reason, it's a very silly card that shouldn't scale the way it does.

Posted By: Areps (11/21/2011 10:18:24 PM)
Rating:

@OmegaSerris:

That wouldn't fly in a tournament at all. Or in a lot of play groups.

It doesn't say "half of their library", it says "the TOP half of their library". That's very important due to topdeck manipulation effects, and spells/effects that put cards on the bottom of libraries. If you played something like Long-Term Plans, Enigma Sphinx or Worldly Tutor, I want to be damn sure that card is in your graveyard. Your method gives a 50/50 chance of it still being in the library. Same applies to if I played Condemn on your Anger or Brawn. I want to make sure that card is on the bottom of your library, not in your graveyard.
Report Abuse

I have a question on this card, any help appreciated:  
  
Say I have a [Consuming Aberration](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Consuming Aberration) out and play this. The Aberration's ability takes effect before the spell resolves; does the Traumatize's ability then check the number of cards in the opponent's library? Or is it the other way round? (This question could apply to other cards..[Mind Sculpt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mind Sculpt) etc?)
